body:
Now a lot of people may say "oh they donated so they deserve it because they donated" yes I know they donated and I respect them for that but I am sick and tired of going onto a nexus match and seeing every single donor on one team. Now some people may not think this is a problem but one thing I've realized is that no matter how good you are you will always get killed by a team of barbarians in nexus. It's ruins it for us non donors who may not have barbarian ( I know I do but some people don't).

This could be done by making sure that there's at least one donor on each team before another donor could join the same team as another donor. 

Please just say -1 if you don't agree and don't be a complete jerk about it :p
body_tagged:

replies.body:
Here:
(pretend  you're a donor)
There's a 5v5v5v5 on Nexus.
You and 4 of your donator friends join red.
1 of you join, but when the rest type /join red, you'll be put onto a random team.

replies.body:
That really stinks and I think there should be a rule for this ):
The worst thing is when you're on a TDM map like Titans and there's a 5v7 with 2 donors-- there's just no way for the 5-person-team to win. I think the best way to fix this is to make a system where donors can't change the amount of players on a team by /join *team* by any more than 20%. This means if there's a match with 5v5, if you and your donator friend tried to join, both of you couldn't because you're changing the amount of players on that team using /join *team* by over 20%. If you're transferring 5 to 6, you're increasing 5 by 20%. This means when you're /join *team*ing, you're changing the player amount by 20%. Your friend then has to do play on the other team because if (s)he /join *team friend is on*, she'd increase the team amount by 40%-- you're going from 5 to 7. This can also be shown as an inequality. (If the amount of donors using /join *team* is x, and the amount of players on the other team is y,) x ≤ .2y. If there are 5 people on a team, this means only 1 can join (1 ≤ 1).
I don't exactly know which side I'm on, though, because it's fun to be with a lot of your friends but sometimes it can be unfair ):
replies.body_tagged:

This means if there's a match with 5v5, if you and your donator friend tried to join, both of you couldn't because you're changing the amount of players on that team using /join *team* by over 20%. If you're transferring 5 to 6, you're increasing 5 by 20%. This means when you're /join *team*ing, you're changing the player amount by 20%. Your friend then has to do play on the other team because if (s)he /join *team friend is on*, she'd increase the team amount by 40%-- you're going from 5 to 7. I don't exactly know which side I'm on, though, because it's fun to be with a lot of your friends but sometimes it can be unfair ):

replies.body:
-1


If we donated, we have all the right to do whatever we would like with it. if it upsets non-donors simply leave the match :P Even if the "TS Crew" does stack team sometimes it easily gets balanced out because we do tell each other not to join the team. Also if it really gets u killed a lot just easily sneak around, You have teammates use them to your advantage. But it is possible to teamstack as a non donor. You just have to wait until a spot on the team you want is open then join. I know some people have learnt this from Walls :P
